channel.title: A Call For Questions
channel.description:
I've been really inspired by both the talent and enthusiasm of everybody here. I'd like to give a little back by sharing some of my knowledge.
My musical tastes mean I'm of little use in making drops or wubs (am I doing it right?), but I do have a degree and about 20 years experience working as an audio engineer.
I've spent the past few days putting together a bunch short, actionable tips you can use to improve your tracks using nothing but Auxy.
So far I've focussed mainly on basic mixing and mono compatibility, but if there is anything you'd like me to cover, please let me know.

item.title: A Call For Questions
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
OK, been living with a pair of Sennheiser HD 380 Pro for the past couple of days.

Very clean sound. Already helping me find a couple of issues with my mixes, which will help me develop better mixing habits. Very useful. Very comfortable too.

To my still as-yet-untrained ear, it seems like clean representation across the lows, mids and highs. Highs aren’t screaming and lows aren’t muddy.

It’s a bit alarming at first, having such an uncoloured sound. Felt a little clinical. And I wasn’t sure if I liked it. But after a little while messing with my levels on my Audio Interface, I think I’ve got a halfway decent reference now. (My headphone volume dials are no longer maxed out.

They’ll be strictly for the reference and mixing, not for regular listening.

But, I will revisit the settings on my Sony MDR-XB950B1 listening headphones to possibly trim back on some of that extra-extra bass. (Ironically, I bought them for the extra bass, while replacing a second pair of badly treated AKG Y50 to die on me. Fwiw, the AKG Y50 are also quite honestly balanced considering they’re regular listening headphone aimed at ‘style’, not mixing/monitoring. AKG are quite reliable and honest across the board, sound-wise. (I didn’t want that honesty at the time.

It’ll also help me use my Sennheiser Momentum M2 IEi in-ear more knowingly.

I suspect having — and regularly using — a good pair of reference/monitor headphones will ‘retrain’ my ears to better appreciate subtlety and be more discerning — and make me a better ‘listener’.

 
-
 
[Edit: Seems we should all be buying these now…

nura

nuraphone - Hear every note. Feel every beat | nura

We all hear differently. The nuraphone uses a self-learning engine to automatically tune to your unique hearing bringing your music into stunning focus.

Read full topic

item.title: A Call For Questions
item.dc:creator: Zeph
item.description:
The ATH m50x are good and dependable, and are reknown for their accuracy, clarity, frequency response, and budget friendliness (they are the best within the $200 price range). I personally own the ATH MSR7s. The only complaint I would have is that the fit is not ideal for my head size. So if you are looking for studio headphones, make sure that you will be able to have them on for 4 hours at least. My MSR7s broke in soon enough, but they were really uncomfortable when I got them. IMHO don’t look at anything above 300, to a beginning musician, anything over that is hard to appreciate.

Read full topic

item.title: A Call For Questions
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
moemx:

I know this is slightly of topic - but would you have any recommendations for headphones when it comes to ideal audio transfer using auxy @nrgb?

The most important thing to look for when buying headphones (or speakers) is a flat frequency response.

Most consumer headphones will boost certain frequencies (like a bit of bass boost) because it generally sounds better to the average listener.

This is problematic for music producers because they aren’t hearing an accurate representation of their song.

If you mix your tracks on bassy headphones you may find that they are actually lacking bottom end when you play them on a flat sound system.

If you’re aware that your gear adds a little colour, you can learn to compensate, but it’s generally easier to not have to.

Without knowing your budget it’s hard to recommend something, but once you’ve settled on a pair I would do a little googling to see what others are saying. (the gearslutz forum is a good start)

As a starting point try AKG, Audio Technica, Beyerdynamic or Sennheiser.

gearslutz.com

Best Headphones (under $200) - Gearslutz Pro Audio Community

Best headphones under $200 In an ideal world we’d all be working with a nice set of high-end...

gearslutz.com

Ten of the best headphones over $300 - Gearslutz Pro Audio Community

Ten of the best headphones over $300 Having established ten of the best headphones under $200 we...

Attack Magazine – 23 Mar 15

Ten Of The Best: Headphones For Music Production - Attack Magazine

We offer a selection of our recommended headphones for studio use, picking out our top choices at a range of price points.

item.title: A Call For Questions
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
Auxy:

We appreciate that there are styles and occasions that call for more headroom, and if this is something people are looking for, I think a better solution would be to add e.g. a setting for the master effects instead of suggesting that people turn down the levels. I can guarantee you that there’s plenty of headroom in the mix bus, and what you refer to as clipping is mainly coming from the limiter in the final mix stage.

I’d appreciate some access to the master effects.
Part of my motivation for recording everything at a lower level is to avoid the limiter.

Read full topic

item.title: A Call For Questions
item.dc:creator: Db909
item.description:
And thank you so much for that! I’ve noticed recently that for me when I’m having an issue with something not standing out like i want it to, it’s usually an arrangement problem rather than not enough headroom. So I’ve been going through and rewriting parts so I don’t have a bunch of stuff competing in the same register and once I did that, everything started geling much better and the whole mix was LOUD AS @*^%! Some leads were so in your face I had to think of ways to soften them up a bit. So I think the system works really well. Even if you do compose sloppily overlapping parts intended to stand out, you can still get a decent mix like I have before. Just turn all the faders down and start from there.

Read full topic

item.title: A Call For Questions
item.dc:creator: Auxy
item.description:
I should also mention that our philosophy is to try and pack as much “mix intelligence” into the app as possible, so that people don’t have to spend years learning mix techniques. So whenever we see someone hacking things together or complaining about “not getting enough bass” or similar things, we try to figure out a way to solve that without forcing the user to change his/her workflow too much.

There’s already a lot of stuff baked into the app that you’re probably not aware of. One example is that we auto tune the sub part of each kick to fit the currently selected key. “It just works!”

Read full topic

item.title: A Call For Questions
item.dc:creator: Auxy
item.description:
Great initiative!

To clarify though, Auxy is designed to have a pretty maxed out mix with little headroom, since that’s how modern tracks usually sound. We’ve spent quite a lot of time with Grammy-winning mix engineer Niklas Flyckt, who currently mixes all of Galantis’ tracks to name one example, working out settings that will make tracks sound like finished tracks in the typical genres you would create with Auxy.

We appreciate that there are styles and occasions that call for more headroom, and if this is something people are looking for, I think a better solution would be to add e.g. a setting for the master effects instead of suggesting that people turn down the levels. I can guarantee you that there’s plenty of headroom in the mix bus, and what you refer to as clipping is mainly coming from the limiter in the final mix stage.

Read full topic
